awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding the Source of the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) Predictability and its Impact on the Mid-latitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
The Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) is one of the main sources for the subseasonal predictability. The MJO is a special type of organized tropical convection systems which is distinct from others types by its vast horizontal spatial scale, subseasonal time scale, and eastward propagation over the Indo-Pacific warm pool. Enhanced or suppressed convection associated with the MJO affects global weather and climate, thereby providing a source of predictability in the subseasonal time scale. Therefore, understanding the essential dynamics and predictability of the MJO is key to improving subseasonal prediction in the tropics as well as MJO-related phenomena in the mid-latitude. The objectives of this study are to understand the predictability of the MJO and its impacts on predictability of high-impact weather events (such as extreme precipitation along the west coast). The main tasks are (i) to investigate the theoretical limit of the MJO, (ii) to investigate the physical processes for MJO propagation and the impact of the mean state change, and (iii) to examine the underlying mechanisms of the associations of MJO with extreme precipitation events. The research project will utilize satellite observations, reanalysis, and numerical experiments with a climate model.

Improving our understanding of subseasonal predictability will have global impacts on agriculture, commerce, healthcare, and food production. Better prediction of the MJO and related high-impact extreme precipitation events will provide policy makers, emergency managers, and other stakeholders with advanced warnings to prepare for mitigation measures. The goal of the educational activities is to increase diversity in atmospheric science by increasing the number of under-represented minority and women students. More specifically, the objectives are (i) to build strong collaborations with local community colleges in order to foster collaborative growth with their atmospheric science programs, (ii) to increase the number of under-represented minority students that transfer from community colleges to 4-year atmospheric science programs, and (iii) to culminate with their studies either into the atmospheric science workforce or graduate school. The educational activities will focus on enhancing computer programming skills and on improving research ability for under-represented minority and women students, thereby increasing diversity in the atmospheric science field.

por.por_cntn:
There has been a growing interest in the scientific, operational, and application communities in providing forecasts for the subseasonal time range - a range that lies between the conventional medium-range weather (up to 2 weeks) and seasonal (3-12 months) forecasts. The subseasonal forecast is particularly important since many management decisions, such as in water management, agriculture and food security, fall into this range. The Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) is the main source of subseasonal predictability for both the tropics and mid-latitudes. The MJO is a special type of organized tropical convection characterized by large zonal scale (wavenumber 1-5), subseasonal time scale (30-60 days), and eastward propagation over the Indo-Pacific warm pool. MJO associated enhanced or suppressed convection affects global weather and climate, and extreme events such as the Atmospheric Rivers. Our NSF project was designed to foster improved understanding of the essential dynamics and predictability of the MJO and MJO-teleconnections, and has provided guidance on how the forecasting system need to be modified to improve simualating MJO and MJO teleconnections. In particular, the following outcomes have resulted from this successful project, which are documented in the 22 peer reviewed studies:

1) We have demonstrated that the state-of-the-art forecasting systems have MJO prediction skill out to 3-4 weeks, which is 2-3 weeks lower than its potential predictability. We found that models fail to predict the MJO convection, especially for the MJO events starting from the Indian Ocean and crossing the Maritime Continent. This information provides guidance on what aspects in MJO prediction and simulation need to be examined in detail to improve subseasonal forecasts.

2) We have demonstrated that the MJO skill reduction is largely attributed to biases in the moisture advection processes in the Indo-Pacific which is associated with a drier low troposphere. We found that this is because models produce more frequent occurrence of light precipitation rates and simulate a transition to stronger precipitation rates at lower humidity than in observations. This information provides guidance of what aspects of forecast models need to be improved to produce better MJO.

3) We have demonstrated that the MJO and stratospheric Quasi-Biennial Oscillation (QBO) are closely linked in the observation, while the current forecast and climate models do not reproduce the observed relationship. We found that both errors in simulating MJO and QBO structure is the main reason for poor simulation.

4) We have demonstrated that Artificial Intelligence techniques can improve the MJO prediction. We show that with Deep Learning bias correction, multi-model forecast errors in MJO amplitude and phase are significantly reduced and models show greatest improvement for MJO events starting from the Indian Ocean and crossing the Maritime Continent.

5) We have led the effort of developing a standardized MJO teleconnection diagnostics by defining a set of MJO teleconnection metrics that enables an objective evaluation of model simulations, a fair model-to-model comparison, and a consistent tracking of model improvement. This diagnostic provides the scientific community with new insights on which physical processes are important for better prediction of the MJO teleconnections.

6) We have demonstrated that Atmospheric Rivers (ARs) are closely related to tropical climate variability. We developed a object-based tracking algorithm to define the AR life cycle which help advance our understanding of AR dynamics and its associated extreme precipitation related to MJO and monsoon. In addition to AR, storm track and air pollution modulated by the MJO and QBO were examined.

7) Two graduate students have obtained their PhD, and 3 undergraduate students from Universities, 4 undergraduate students local Community Colleges, and 1 high-school student have participated in this project in some form, supporting the training of the next generation of atmospheric science researchers.

8) The PI visited the local Community College several times and gave lectures on how to analyze climate data and introduced various research in atmospheric science, with particular focus on the tropical climate and mid-latitude weather interaction. We also train students to develop scientific presentation skills. On average, about 5-8 students from local Community College participated in each lecture.
